title: Community fridge helps those struggling with food insecurity
body: Sashauana McKain used her downtime during the pandemic to give back to her community. She saw the idea for a community fridge online and asked her own Twitter feed if an Orlando version would be beneficial. Quickly, the idea became a reality. "The fridge is owned by the community and not one sole person," said Vonika Colas, a local artist who helped make the fridge unique. Open to the public 24/7,  anyone can drop off food donations and those experiencing food insecurity can get a free meal. All food is pre-packaged and there is no raw meat and seafood, to be as safe as possible. Learn more about this helpful idea in the video player above. Stitch brings you heartwarming stories from a community just like yours. It celebrates our hometown heroes and is inspired by communities, revitalized.
